Hi Rich,

Not sure what the motif is, but as for the way names are read, ty=
pically the
kunyomi is used or the Japanese pronunciation. However, even sw=
ord-smiths
are given onyomi or Sino-Japanese nicknames. Perhaps the most fa=
mous is
Nagayoshi, who is typically called Chogi. There is also Hiroyoshi, =
whose
nickname is Hiroga. Teimei may be a Japanese nickname for Sadanobu. I=
 am
pretty sure you would read his signature using the kunyomi. On the othe=
r
hand, there are lots of fittings makers whose name is read using the onyo=
mi
-- Tomei, Somin, all the Goto guys. Even the Omori guys' names are
prono=
unced here in Japan using the onyomi. I hope this is sufficiently
confusing=
.

Gordon

e way more correct than the

 Sadanaga from time to 
time ). I see Nihonto Koza says Sadanobu, I have he=
ard that the Japanese 
refer to him as Teimei.
